---
title: Personality
layout: post
---

**Personality -** The patterns of feelings, motives, & behavior.
# Psychoanalytic Theory of Personality
Unconscious mind shapes behavior. There are 3 levels of the mind: conscious, preconscious, & unconscious.
## The Id, Ego, & Super-Ego
**The Id-**The unconscious part of the mind, operates on the pleasure principle<br>
**The Ego-** Developed out of the id and operates on the *reality principle*.<br>
**The Super-Ego-** Develops later in childhood, operates on the *moral principle*, makes you feel guilty when you do something wrong.<br>
**The Ego** cannot fully control the **Id**
## Defense Mechanisms
Ego matures & must manage the conflict of the Super-Ego and Id.<br>
Ego developed "Defense Mechanisms". It is a way of keeping threating thoughts out of mind. 
1. **Repression-** Pushing thoughts away.
2. **Rationalization-** Offering what appears to be logical explanations.
3. **Reaction Formation-** Preventing unacceptable feelings/ideas from being directly expressed by expressing the polar opposite.
4. **Displacement-** Redirect thought on another.
5. **Projection-** Perceiving your own aggressive urges not in yourself, but in others.
6. **Regression-** Resorting to childish behavior.

# Jung's Personality Theory
People are motivated by the desire for growth & wholeness. <br>
**Collective Unconscious-** Inherited memories shared by all humans.
People are born with tendencies to direct attention either to our internal thoughts or the outside world.
# Humanistic Personality Theory
## Person-Centered (Carl Rogers)
![Carl Rogers](data:image/jpeg;base64,)<br>
**Unconditional Positive Regard-** Unquestionable love & Acceptance
**Ideal Self-** The person you want to become.
**Actual Self-** Person you know yourself to be.
You should find someone that has UPR for you.
## Self-Actualization (Abraham Maslow)
![Abraham Maslow](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/e/e0/Abraham_Maslow.jpg/220px-Abraham_Maslow.jpg)<br>
**Self-Actualization-** Processes of filling your potential.
You are secure in who you are, and you're loving & caring. You experience **"peak experiences"**- brief but intense moments of joy. People at the top of the pyramid have more peak experiences.
# Trait Theory
**Trait Perspective-** Personality consists of stable behavior patterns over time & situations. <br>
Trait theory asks more of how compared to the other theories why. There are 5 basic factors that apply to all ages, societies, and cultures. 5
## Five Factors (OCEAN)
1. **Openness-** Open to experiences, looks for new ways, look at the world in awe.
2. **Conscientious-** Willingness to conform and follow through on agreements, organized, dependable, & ambitious.
3. **Extroverted-** Seek out & enjoy company, confident, optimistic, social interactions are easy.
4. **Agreeableness-** courteous & sympathetic.
5. **Neuroticism-** Anxious, insecure, & high-strung

# Social Cognitive Theory
**Social-Cognitive Theory-** How people analyze and use information about themselves & others. Founded by Albert Bandura he said that people learn through observation.<br>
**Reciprocal Determinism-** personality emerges from an ongoing mutual interaction among actions and environments.<br>
**Self-efficacy-** your belief about your ability to perform behaviors that should bring desired outcome.<br>
**Self-serving Bias-** the tendency to take credit for success while denying blame for failure.<br>
## Locus of Control
The degree to which you expect things happen to you based on your own actions or things beyond your control is our **Locus of Control**. **External LOC** things happen to us because it's outside of our control.
# Measuring Personality
**Projective Test-** A test that asks the subject to respond to ambiguous situations in a way that reveals unconscious. Tests like Rorschach Inkblot or Thematic Apperception Test<br>
**Thematic Apperception Test (T.A.T)-** Project inner feeling based on a story that makes you up.
## Objective Tests
Direct, clear questions about your conscious thoughts, feelings, and behaviors. It is self-reported they include true and false questions, multiple-choice questions, no single correct answers. 
M.M.P.I.(Minnesota Multiphasic Personality Inventory) it is the most used test, and it has 567 questions that measure 10 different clinical scales used to identify psychological interests.
